instruction: Can the HSI-NIR-SIMCA method be considered superior to traditional methods for the automatic identification of microplastics in beach sand?
Output: Yes, the HSI-NIR-SIMCA method can be considered superior to traditional methods for the automatic identification of microplastics in beach sand. The method utilizes near-infrared hyperspectral imaging (HSI-NIR) which allows for high throughput screening and automatic identification of microplastics with minimum sample preparation. It can detect small colorless microplastics that may be imperceptible to visual inspection or manual pick up. The method operates directly on the entire sample or its retained fraction after sieving, eliminating the need for spectroscopic subsampling. The high-speed analysis of line-scan instrumentation enables multiple microplastics to be assessed simultaneously. The method has been validated for hundreds of microplastics collected in the environment, showing high sensitivity and specificity for different types of microplastics. It is also robust and reliable for identifying weathered microplastics together with other matrix constituents. Additionally, the HSI-NIR-SIMCA method can be applied to microplastics extracted from other matrices after sample preparation. Overall, the HSI-NIR-SIMCA method offers a faster and less laborious approach to automatically identify microplastics in beach sand compared to traditional methods.
